results.statement:
ASCO: American Society of Clinical Oncology; ESMO: European Society of Medical Oncology, ONS: Oncology Nursing Society; CNSA: Cancer Nurses Society of Australia; INS: Infusion Nurses Society; OSHA:
Occupational Safety and Health Administration; CDC: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; NIOSH: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
References: 1. Khetan AK, Palileo-Villanueva LM, Mat-Nasir N, et al. Mortality, cardiovascular disease, and their associations with risk factors in Southeast Asia. JACC Asia. 2024;4(8):624-633. doi:10.1016/j.jaca-
si.2024.05.008
results.reference: Khetan AK, Palileo-Villanueva LM, Mat-Nasir N, et al. Mortality, cardiovascular disease, and their associations with risk factors in Southeast Asia. JACC Asia. 2024;4(8):624-633. doi:10.1016/j.jaca- si.2024.05.008
results.matched_evidence: - 1.Khetan AK.pdf: JACC Asia. 2024 Jul 30;4(8):624-633. doi: 10.1016/j.jacasi.2024.05.008

results.statement:
Why Optimizing IV Chemotherapy Matters. Cancer ranks among the top 3
causes of death in Asia.
results.reference: Khetan AK, Palileo-Villanueva LM, Mat-Nasir N, et al. Mortality, cardiovascular disease, and their associations with risk factors in Southeast Asia. JACC Asia. 2024;4(8):624-633. doi:10.1016/j.jaca- si.2024.05.008
results.matched_evidence: - 1.Khetan AK.pdf: The most common cause of mortality was CVD (38% of mortality), followed by cancer (12%), respiratory diseases (10.5%), infection (8.7%), and injury (4.4%) (Figure 1).

results.statement:
Why Optimizing IV Chemotherapy Matters. Up to 60% of cancer patients
receive chemotherapy as a part
of their treatment.
results.reference: Wilson BE, Jacob S, Yap ML, Ferlay J, Bray F, Barton MB. Estimates of global chemotherapy demands and corresponding physician workforce requirements for 2018 and 2040: a population-based study. Lancet Oncol. 2019;20(6):769-780. doi:10.1016/S1470-2045(19)30163-9 3.Duggan C, Carr PJ, Gavin N, et al. Vascular access devices for prolonged intravenous therapy regimens in people diagnosed with cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2024;2024(9):CD015667. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD015667 4.Garcia MA, Kalecinski J, Oriol M, et al. Cancer patients treated with intravenous chemotherapy for the first time: what are their needs? What do they lack? A qualitative–quantitative mixed approach. Patient Prefer Adherence. 2018;12:1853-1861. doi:10.2147/PPA.S1698105. Bahl A, Johnson S, Alsbrooks K, Mares A, Gala S, Hoerauf K. Defining difficult intravenous access (DIVA): a systematic review. J Vasc Access. 2021;0(0):112972982110596. doi:10.1177/11297298211059648
results.matched_evidence: - 2.Wilson BE,2019.pdf: According to GLOBOCAN estimates,¹ there were approximately 17.0 million new cancer cases and 9.5 million deaths from cancer worldwide (excluding non-melanomatous skin cancers) in 2018.|A growing proportion of these cases are diagnosed in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs), which will account for an estimated 70% of cancer diagnoses by 2040.²

results.statement:
Why Optimizing IV Chemotherapy Matters. Intravenous (IV) chemotherapy is a key treatment modality in oncology care, offering rapid drug delivery and
a systemic response, making it crucial for cancer patients.
results.matched_evidence: - 3.Duggan C, 2024.pdf: Systemic anti-cancer therapy (SACT) has evolved over the past 20 years.|The majority of SACT is delivered intravenously.|Therefore, the insertion of a vascular access device (VAD) is a prerequisite (Kim 2021).

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Difficult Intravenous Access (DIVA) refers to the challenge of securing IV access due to two or more failed attempts
using traditional techniques, absence of visible or palpable veins, or a known history of DIVA.
results.matched_evidence: - 5. Bahl A,2021.pdf: Conclusions: Considering the themes identified, an evidence-driven definition of DIVA is proposed: "when a clinician has two or more failed attempts at PIV access using traditional techniques, physical examination findings are suggestive of DIVA (e.g. no visible or palpable veins) or the patient has a stated or documented history of DIVA."

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. One of the major contributing factors to DIVA is the frequent cannulation attempts for IV chemotherapy
administration, which often results in venous depletion, compromising vein integrity and making future cannulation
more difficult.
results.reference: Eren H. Difficult intravenous access and its management. In: Vascular Access Devices. IntechOpen; 2021. https://www.intechopen.com/chapters/754777. BD-34_DiVA Quantitative Final Report - vFF. [Unpublished internal report].
results.matched_evidence: - 6. Eren H.2021.pdf: Intravenous chemotherapy treatment is one of the most serious causes of the disruption of the vascular structure. Chemotherapy drugs (vesicants, irritants) cause complications such as phlebitis, infiltration, extravasation, thrombophlebitis, and septicemia, manifesting as pain, redness, ulceration, and necrosis along the vein, and stimulate the sympathetic nervous system, thereby causing the vessels to contract and decreasing their fullness and visibility [ ].

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. 7x increase in costs
due to catheter
replacements
results.matched_evidence: - 9.Paterson RS, 2022.pdf: Multiple failed attempts are also associated with escalating healthcare expenditure, with one study reporting a sevenfold increase in costs following multiple failed insertion attempts compared to a single insertion attempt.

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Overall
dissatisfaction
with care
results.matched_evidence: - 11. Twibell2019.pdf: Patients/parents rated distress and dissatisfaction with venipuncture as significantly greater compared with short peripheral catheter blood sampling (P < .001).

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Delays
in treatment
results.reference: Witting MD. IV access difficulty: predictors and clinical outcomes. J Emerg Med. 2012;42(4):483-487.11. Twibell KR, Hofstetter P, Siela D, Brown D, Jones HM. A comparative study of blood sampling from venipuncture and short peripheral catheters in pediatric inpatients. J Infus Nurs. 2019;42(5):239-245. doi:10.1097/NAN.0000000000000338
results.matched_evidence: - 10.Witting2012.pdf: From a patient perspective, each attempt at IV access is painful, and delays in establishing IV access are often delays in obtaining needed care.

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. High risk of
catheter-related
complications
(phlebitis, infection,
and sepsis)
results.reference: Rodriguez-Calero MA, de Pedro-Gomez JE, Molero-Ballester LJ, et al. Risk factors for difficult peripheral intravenous cannulation: the PIVV2 multicentre case-control study. J Clin Med. 2020;9(3):799. doi:10.3390/jcm9030799 13.Sou V, McManus C, Mifflin N, Frost SA, Ale J, Alexandrou E. A clinical pathway for the management of difficult venous access. BMC Nurs. 2017;16(1):64. doi:10.1186/s12912-017-0261-z 14.Gallieni M, Pittiruti M, Biffi R. Vascular access in oncology patients. CA Cancer J Clin. 2008;58(6):323-346. doi:10.3322/ca.2008.0015
results.matched_evidence: - 12.Rodriguez,2020.pdf: DPIVC has been reported to affect 10%-24% of hospitalized adults and is associated with higher rates of catheter failure, provoking more frequent catheter replacement [8]. |This may produce serious complications associated with vascular access, such as phlebitis, extravasation, bruising, haemorrhages, catheter-associated infection and sepsis, thus aggravating morbidity [9,10].

results.statement:
Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Increased pain
impacts patient
experience
results.matched_evidence: - 13.Sou2017.pdf: Many patients are admitted to hospital with non-visible or palpable veins, often resulting in multiple painful attempts at cannulation, anxiety and catheter failure.|Patients with DiVA may undergo multiple, painful at-tempts to gain peripheral venous access [7].|This significant finding illustrates the impact of needle pain which can cause anxiety, phobia and significantly reduce patient satisfaction with the health care facility [21].

results.statement: Vascular Access Complications with Peripheral Intravenous Catheter (PIVC). 25% of cancer patients with vascular access devices experience complications.
results.matched_evidence: - 14.Gallieni M,2008.pdf: Data from a study commissioned by the Food and Drug Administration in the 1990s² showed that the use of VADs is associated with a high complication rate (10% to 25% of all patients with VADs) and a morbidity of at least 10%;

results.statement:
Vascular Access Complications with Peripheral Intravenous Catheter (PIVC). Based on a healthcare professionals' survey on the perceived incidence of complications due to PIVCs in
oncology patients, it was found that:

Evaluation of genotoxic effects induced by exposure to antineoplastic drugs in lymphocytes and exfoliated buccal cells of oncology nurses and pharmacy employees. Mutat Res. 2005;587(1-2):45-51. 21.McDiarmid MA, Oliver MS, Roth TS, Rogers B, Escalante C. Chromosome 5 and 7 abnormalities in oncology personnel handling anticancer drugs. J Occup Environ Med. 2010;52(10):1028-1034. doi:10.1097/JOM.0b013e3181f73ae6
results.matched_evidence: - 15. LeVasseur N,2018.pdf: Medical oncologists and oncology nurses were both asked about the perceived incidence of complications with the various types of venous access (Table II).|Of the listed complications, sclerosis of the veins (31%) and risk of extravasation (7%-17%) were reported for peripheral IVs; no rates were reported for PICCs and ports.
results.page_location: Page 12, section 'What Is the Perceived Incidence of Complications?'

results.statement: Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. Exposure may occur at any point in the journey of a hazardous drug.
results.matched_evidence:
- 16.Nyman,2007.pdf: Health care workers who prepare and administer antineoplastic agents risk exposure to these drugs.
- 17.Wick,2003.pdf: Abstract: Surface contamination with and personnel exposure to antineoplastic agents before and after the implementation of a closed-system protective device were studied.
results.page_location: Page 1, Introduction section, paragraph 1 | Abstract section of the paper

results.statement:
Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. A study of six hospitals found that frequently contacted surfaces at every stage of the hospital medication
system had measurable levels of antineoplastic drug contamination.
results.matched_evidence: - 27.Hon CY,2013.pdf: Our study found that frequently contacted surfaces at every stage of the hospital medication system had measureable levels of antineoplastic drug contamination.

results.statement:
Frequently touched surfaces can pose a risk of hazardous drug (HD) exposure, making routine wipe sampling
essential. HD check detects residues on surfaces, equipment, and handling areas. Real-world data highlights
the need for structured contamination monitoring based on site, frequency, and drug type.
results.matched_evidence:
- 28.Hon CY,2023.pdf: One of the most common means to assess the risk of health care workers' exposure to hazardous drugs is environmental monitoring or surface wipe sampling.7 This is because the route of exposure to hazardous drugs for health care workers is believed to be dermal uptake or skin contact.8,9 Essentially, workers can be exposed if they touch a drug-contaminated surface.
- 29.Kiffmeyer TK, 2013.pdf: The developed monitoring procedure has proven to be suitable as a reliable and affordable tool for routine monitoring of workplace contamination with antineoplastic agents.

results.statement:
Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. A NIOSH survey of 1,954 healthcare professionals revealed that they touched other work surfaces while
wearing chemotherapy gloves:

results.statement: Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. USP <800> recommends sampling surfaces routinely
results.matched_evidence: - 31.USP chapter 800.pdf: Environmental wipe sampling for HD surface residue should be performed routinely (e.g., initially as a benchmark and at least every 6 months, or more often as needed, to verify containment).
results.page_location: Page 6, Section 6. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND CONTROL

results.statement:
Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. "Environmental wipe sampling for HD surface residue
should be performed routinely (e.g., initially as a
benchmark and at least every 6 months, or more often as
needed, to verify containment). [...] Repeat the wipe
sampling to validate that the deactivation/
decontamination and cleaning steps have been effective."
results.matched_evidence: - 31.USP chapter 800.pdf: Environmental wipe sampling for HD surface residue should be performed routinely (e.g., initially as a benchmark and at least every 6 months, or more often as needed, to verify containment).|Repeat the wipe sampling to validate that the deactivation/decontamination and cleaning steps have been effective.
results.page_location: Page 6, Section 6. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND CONTROL

results.statement:
Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Despite advances in oncology care, vascular access and administration of hazardous drugs continue to pose
challenges for healthcare professionals, including oncology nurses, vascular access specialists,
pharmacists, oncologists, quality and safety officers involved in VAD and IV chemotherapy care.
results.matched_evidence:
- 18. ISOPP.pdf: Despite advances in oncology care, vascular access and administration of hazardous drugs continue to pose
challenges for healthcare professionals, including oncology nurses, vascular access specialists,
pharmacists, oncologists, quality and safety officers involved in VAD and IV chemotherapy care.
- 19.Abu-Alhaija D,2023.pdf: Chemotherapeutic drugs are sources of occupational hazard to healthcare workers.
results.page_location: Statement appears in the prompt itself, which is a summary of the paper's content. | Page 15, Conclusion section, paragraph 1

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. The risks of handling hazardous drugs are real and significant:
results.matched_evidence:
- 18. ISOPP.pdf: Occupational exposure to hazardous drugs and the potential
health risk to healthcare workers first became a recognised
safety concern in the 1970s.

results.statement:
Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Staff handling HD show up to a 5x increase
in certain chromosomal aberrations.
results.matched_evidence:
- 20.Cavallo,2005.pdf: Our CA analysis showed in exposed groups a significant increase (about 2.5-fold) of structural chromosomal aberrations, with a particular relevance for breaks (up to 5.0-fold) confirming the study of Burgaz et al. [23] who also found an increase of the CA frequency in a group of 26 nurses handling antineoplastic drugs.
- 21. Mcdiarmid,2010.pdf: The highly exposed group, however, when compared with the nonexposed has a general trend of higher abnormality frequencies for almost every outcome examined, reaching statistical significance with excesses in structural abnormalities of chromosome 5 (0.02 vs 0.18; P = 0.04 for the nonexposed vs the highly exposed, respectively) and total changes in chromosome 5 (0.04 vs 0.29; P = 0.01).|Table 6 was constructed in a similar fashion as was Table 5 but using only alkylating agent handling events as the exposure measure.
results.page_location: Page 5, right column, last paragraph | Page 3, Results Section | Page 5, Results Section

results.statement:
Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Increased relative risk of leukemia for oncology
nurses, 2.8x increase in non-melanoma
cancer, and 3.7x increase in non-Hodgkin's
lymphoma in pharmacy techs.
results.matched_evidence: - 22.Skov T, 1992.pdf: The relative risk (RR) for leukaemia was significantly increased (10.65) but based on only two cases, one of acute myeloblastic and one of chronic myeloid leukaemia.

results.statement:
Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Three consecutive nurses handling cytostatic
agents had liver damage.
results.reference: Sotaniemi EA, Sutinen S, Arranto AJ, et al. Liver damage in nurses handling cytostatic agents. Acta Med Scand. 1983;214(3):181-189. 25.Lawson CC, Rocheleau CM, Whelan EA, et al. Occupational exposures among nurses and risk of spontaneous abortion. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2012;206(4):327.e1-327.e8. 26.Hemminki K, Kyronen P, Lindbohm ML. Spontaneous abortions and malformations in the offspring of nurses exposed to anaesthetic gases, cytostatic drugs, and other potential hazards in hospitals. J Epidemiol Community Health. 1985;39(2):141-147. 27.Hon CY, Teschke K, Chu W, Demers P, Venners S. Antineoplastic drug contamination of surfaces throughout the hospital medication system in Canadian hospitals. J Occup Environ Hyg. 2013;10(7):374-383. doi:10.1080/15459624.2013.789743
results.matched_evidence: - 24.Sotaniemi EA,1983.pdf: Three consecutive head nurses developed liver injury after years of handling cytostatic drugs.

results.statement:
Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. 2x greater risk of miscarriage among staff
handling antineoplastic drugs.
results.matched_evidence: - 25.Lawson CC, 2012.pdf: After adjusting for age, parity, shift work, and hours worked, antineoplastic drug exposure was associated with a 2-fold increased risk of spontaneous abortion, particularly with early spontaneous abortion before the 12th week, and 3.5-fold increased risk among nulliparous women.
